awd_titl_txt: Program for Development and Demonstration of Pioneering Accelerator Technology
awd_abstract_narration:
Accelerators are powerful tools for science and engines for industry, with enormous impact on society. This research program by Cornell University implements innovative accelerator concepts in pioneering, working accelerator devices. Specifically, this program focuses on two transformational topics: (1) The development of very compact and energy efficient superconducting cavities for particle acceleration, which will enable a new class of powerful, compact accelerators, and (2) dramatic improvements in luminosity of particle colliders via a technique called optical stochastic cooling which promises to significantly improve the quality of particle beams.  Cornell University's work on pioneering accelerator technology paves the way for new accelerators that are ever more powerful probes of materials, biological systems, molecules, atoms, nuclei and the most fundamental particles in nature.  This program will impact accelerators for industry as well. In particular, the technologies that Cornell will develop are essential for the accelerators that are critical tools for medicine, national defense, and perhaps for safe nuclear energy. This research also contributes directly to the education of undergraduate and graduate students in cutting-edge science, engineering and technology, a skillset urgently needed for the U.S. workforce. During summers, students from community colleges will be mentored in research in an environment that would otherwise be unavailable to them. For many it will be a life altering experience.

Superconducting RF (SRF) is the gold-standard for modern accelerators and the most energy efficient means of accelerating a beam of charged particles, but complexity, size, and cost of the current SRF technology until now have limited SRF cavity application to large-scale scientific accelerators. However, recent developments have resulted in drastic reductions of the RF surface resistance of SRF cavities, allowing for a new generation of compact SRF cavities. The SRF research part of this program will focus on the development of such very compact, high-frequency SRF cavities. These will enable completely new SRF-driven accelerators for small-scale university, industrial, national security, and medical applications, by offering robust, compact, energy efficient, and high beam power capable accelerating structures. Optical stochastic cooling promises many orders of magnitude faster cooling rates than conventional stochastic cooling systems that operate in the microwave regime. A cooler beam is more readily focused to high intensity. With cooled hadron beams, proton and heavy ion colliders can achieve significantly higher luminosities; and optical stochastic cooling is presently the only candidate technology for active cooling of electrons, positrons, and muons.

por.por_cntn:
This research program has developed novel accelerator techniques and hardware by (1) advancing optical stochastic cooling of particle beams, and (2) by advancing very compact high-frequency superconducting radio-frequency cavities for acceleration of particle beams. This project provided much needed training of students and young scientists in cutting-edge science, engineering and technology as urgently needed for the U.S. workforce. In total, this award supported training of four post-docs, six graduate students, and six undergraduate students.

Optical stochastic cooling

Optical stochastic cooling (OSC) is a technology that promises to reduce the phase space volume of high energy particle beams, and to increase beam intensity. High intensity translates to higher collision rates for proton and heavy ion colliders like the Large Hadron Collider (LHC), the Electron Ion Collider (EIC) and a muon collider.

Optical stochastic cooling is fundamentally a high bandwidth feedback system that relies on undulators as both pickup and kicker. The radiation from charged particles in the pickup undulator is amplified and then coupled back to those same particles in the kicker undulator, with the relative phase of particles and radiation chosen to achieve cooling. The undulator radiation is propagated through a bypass that short cuts the path of the particle beam to allow time for amplification of the radiation and timely reunification with the particle beam in the kicker undulator.

To achieve sufficient delay of the particle beam with respect to the path of the undulator radiation, the pickup and kicker in the OSC experiment in the Cornell Electron Storage Ring (CESR), are placed 80 meters apart. The light path for this experiment has been assembled, and synchrotron light from adjacent bend magnets (in lieu of undulator radiation) has been successfully propagated through the light path. The arrival times at the kicker of particles and the light they produce in the pickup must be synchronized to an accuracy of less than an optical wavelength, which for this experiment is 780 nm. To test this synchronization, an interference pattern is formed with radiation from the bend magnet at the pickup location with that of the bend magnet at the kicker location. A feedback system based on an Electro-Optic Modulator (EOM) will correct the path-error accumulated in both the light and particle paths. In addition to demonstrating stability, the fringe visibility of the pattern will quantify the cooling range of an OSC feedback system. The aim is to demonstrate that the requisite stabilization can be achieved in a real-world accelerator.  Meanwhile, engineering design of the helical undulators that will serve as pickup and kicker has been completed. Operation of the storage ring (CESR) with magnetic configuration and in an energy range compatible with an experimental test of active optical cooling has been demonstrated.

High-efficiency, high-frequency Compact SRF Cavities

This work has demonstrated that high-frequency superconducting radio-frequency (SRF) niobium and Nb3Sn accelerator cavities are not only feasible, but can be optimal for maximizing cryogenic efficiency. This work has also made important contributions to our understanding of the science of high-field superconductivity, including high-frequency effects, and has stimulated new interests in the condensed matter field on these topics, e.g., as part of the research of the NSF Science and Technology Center for Bright Beams.

This breakthrough will allow for a new generation of high-frequency, very compact superconducting RF driven particle accelerators, e.g., for small-scale science accelerators at universities. Because of their small size, energy efficiency, and high beam power, high-frequency SRF accelerators have the potential of wide societal impact by enabling completely new SRF-based accelerators for industrial, national security, and medical applications. The outcomes from this project will support adoption of SRF accelerator technology outside of the bounds of science, which will be transformational for many applications.
